Campus.Review: HOT summers and Cold winters
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Paradise. The weather is great during winter months, but it gets super humid during the summer and into September.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The Duke wireless network is amazing, always providing HD streams of TV shows.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Plenty of students go to Chapel Hill on weekends for parties, and there is NHL team nearby.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Overall, the buses are pretty reliable, though it certainly can get old waiting for a bus. Many students have cars, making transportation off-campus easy.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Cameron Indoor Stadium! What separates Duke from peer schools is the beauty of its campus, especially Cameron. It is one of the 5 best stadiums in sports, and going to games is an absolute blast, even if you know little about the game.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: People love to hate on the parking system and policies here, but I haven't had any issues with either. Compared to other universities' parking configurations, Duke is heaven on earth.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The facilities are in excellent condition.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Transportation is good at this university.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Th local atmosphere is wonderful.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The weather has no affect on my campus experience.  The campus is beautiful despite all weather conditions.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Taxis are cheap, and the busses run frequently enough
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I love the weather, but sometimes it acts crazy and starts ice raining out of nowhere.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Durham seems to be a great place to live. I would potentially stay.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Most students have their own laptops, so it is probably more supply/demand, but if I have forgotten mine, I can usually find a computer in the library.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I think that cars should have decals instead of removable window hangers. I got a ticket just for forgetting to put it up, and it was in my cup holder.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are a lot of e-print stations but sometimes they are broken
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Buses take you between East, West, and Central campuses. They run frequently, although less frequently on weekends.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: It's usually bright and sunny.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Parking is not the greatest.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: It's ok... Not much to do except go to the same parties.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Not bad...   :)
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Wifi is available everywhere and is fast. You are allocated money for printing, but if you somehow run out, they just give you more at no additional charge. The campus offers numerous computer labs, but most people just use their laptops for everything they need.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The facilities are amazing at Duke. Both Brodie gym on east campus and Wilson on west are beautiful and newly upgraded. The libraries are the best and provide study spots for every type of student.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: It never gets too cold. It does rain a lot, but I personally see rainy days as the best days to study. Fall and spring are absolutely perfect in Durham and warrant an abundance of outdoor activities such as tennis, sand volleyball, and just hanging out outside playing corn hole
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Its fine I guess. Its hot and humid in the summer, anbd typically snows in the winter. The equinoxes are nice though. If this plays a factor in choosing school, then dont go here, because you dont belong here.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Does the job. Pretty good internet and OIT is very helpful
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: We have buses, and they do a pretty good job. Nothing special
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: this area actually has a lot to offer culturally and in the restaurant scene
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: lately it has been very back and forth, it's not typical, but I am over the snow!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The weather can change dramatically. It could be snowing one day and be 65 and sunny the next.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: You are always connected at Duke. You don't need a laptop but it makes everything easier
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Not too cold, but don't assume it is always warm.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Going home sucks to get used to slow internet.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The buses don't go very far into Durham, but they run 24/7 if you need to get somewhere nearby or from one campus to another. They are extremely safe and reliable.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: I bought a Mac through the school, got a great deal on it, and can pay it off over the four years I'm here! It's a great system.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The weather is extremely mild in the winter and warm in the summer. It rarely rains and is pretty beautiful and sunny every days. Blue skies become typical!
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The athletic spaces are great. Duke is a very beautiful campus and there are number of places that support student life.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Basketball. Fans are pretty intense. There are copious resources for research and extracurricular learning.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Weather didn't really have much of an affect on my college experience. There weather is typical of a northern southern state. We have all of the seasons and it snows in durham occasionally.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Transportation on campus is pretty convenient and runs frequently. But it can be challenging arranging a ride/pick up from the airport considering it is 20 minutes away.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Durham is an okay city. Students have had a lot of bad incidents off campus but my experiences has been great. While there many not be much to do beyond a local bar/club that many undergrads flock to, Durham has a number of amazing restaurants to suit anyone's taste.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Computers are school are great. We have access to both MAC and PC technologies that have variety of software such as word processing, statistical analysis and videography. Printing is ubiquitous and free. usually, I don't have any network issues. You don't need to have a computer but having one would be more convenient.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: 80% of the year is beautiful and warm and sunny.  The other 20% is raining and cold and miserable.  Still better than the Northeast.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Durham is a cool little town.  There are certainly places you should not go at night, but it has a decent amount of culture and personality for a small town in NC.  If you want more big city feel, Raleigh is close and Charlotte is only a few hours away.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Parking is one of Duke's logistical weaknesses.  Too few spots, too many students, and too much of a distance.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Durham has actually become an awesome college city. The food is unbelievable - endless great restaurants with a unique feel and menu. Every time you're out at a different one you'll find a new experience. There aren't a ton of bars students go to a la a bar strip, but there are plenty of venues that Greek organizations rent out and a couple of hot spots everyone goes to on certain nights.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Student life is great. There are opportunities to get involved in every organization one could imagine, and almost all of these organizations are very well-funded by the Universityl
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The library, gym, student center, and general facilities are great. They are state of the art and well-kept.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: CarShare, Bull City Connector (which is free), and megabus are all cheap options from getting around. Also, a lot of places in Durham are within walking distance.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Much better weather than up north.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Wifi is awesome, printing super convenient and FREE (it's totally unnecessary to bring your own printer), computer labs are usually free, and come with programs like Final Cut, garage band, and Photoshop.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Durham has a lot of great food options (although not as many as they advertise in the admissions package they give you).  I haven't spent a lot of time off campus, although I know there is plenty to do. The city is really accessible, because they have free buses going throughout Durham. There's a farmer's market every Saturday, where a lot of people in the community go to. It feels really southern and quaint. There's a stereotype that Duke is full of obnoxious, privileged kids, and basically everyone in North Carolina hates Duke because UNC is our huge rival. Knowing the people here, I wouldn't agree with that stereotype at all. Everyone's proud of going to Duke, but they don't really shove that in people's faces or flaunt it.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: computer tech assistance in same building as my classes
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: not too much snow but very hot and humid in the summer
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: limited spots in a lot that i pay for-parking is horrible
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: I don't think I utilize on-campus transportation options as much as I could.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Durham is a pathetic little city... avoid it at all costs. There is almost nothing to do, and the camaraderie between the city and the university is pretty much nonexistent. Much of the city is dangerous, especially at night.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: You can have access to computers really easily
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: If you want to go shopping, you will need to drive
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Buses with different routes can take you to any place you want to go
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: You can always find the place to go to meet your demand
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: RDU Airport is really awesome. You need a car if you wanna live on Central/Off-campus.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Solid. Really solid. Coldest it gets is 35. Yep...
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I once got a $200 ticket (YES, 200 DOLLARS) for parking in a parking lot that I had a pass to. I parked in a spot not designated. Absolutely outrageous, a speeding ticket costs twice as less.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The disconnect between Durham and Duke University is incredible. Two totally different worlds.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Parking is available close to the School of Nursing for on campus classes.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Duke University offers the best in cutting edge technology and maintains an appreciation for gothic beauty.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Not much snow, and a light-moderate amount of rain. Duke does have all four seasons, but in general the weather is mild enough to not be a bother.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Parking is generally worry-free for freshman undergraduates, and decent for non-freshman undergrads. For special events, however, parking tends to be limited - for instance, students can't park in their usual spots during events such as basketball games.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The parking is plentiful, and reasonably priced, but because there are three different campuses, there are three different stickers, and you can only park on your campus during weekdays.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Usually bright and sunny. The gorgeous weather ensures that students are often in an optimistic and upbeat frame of mind.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The computer labs at Duke are pretty nice: mostly new computers, big screens, not crowded... However most people don't use them unless it's for a class because it's more convenient to use your own laptop. For printing, we have eprint, which is broken half of the time. There is usually one eprint station per dorm/building.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Durham is not really a college town. You would need a car to get anywhere interesting (for example, Southpoint mall is a 20 minute drive). That being said, there are some great restaurants nearby. Most students learn to adapt to this and center their lives around the campus
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There are computer labs in every dorm and there are plenty of computers provided at all the campus libraries. Because there are so many accessible computers, if yours happens to break you usually will not find yourself running around looking for one.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Public Transportation is very good around Durham and on Duke Campus. Duke buses on different schedules but they usually stop running around 2am-4am throughout the week and weekends. Durham buses run on a strict schedule, which makes it easy to plan.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Durham has plenty to offer in the arts, dining, festivities and shopping. Durham is home to Duke University and the Durham Bulls. Duke is not the biggest party school or the craziest party town, but our neighboring schools provide the night life and it gives Duke students the benefit of being away from the hussle and bussle of being built into a city.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Besides the rain lately, the weather is absolutely beautiful here.  Even with the rain, the trees are so green it is amazing.  Plus rain or shine, the Duke Gardens are always stunning.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Duke uses eprint, so you can print anywhere on campus and you get $35 of printing free before you start having to pay, and most people don't even use the whole amount.  The wireless network is strong and available pretty much everywhere.  Having a personal computer is very helpful and most people have them, but you definitely don't need a printer and most people don't have one.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Printing on campus is excellent. Wifi coverage is excellent, too. You definitely benefit more from a personal computer, here. But there is a lot of computer availability in the libraries, so if you don't have a personal computer, you would be okay.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Really no need for a car on campus. Parking spaces are convenient, unless you're trying to park near the rec center while a basketball game is going on.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Great college area. Near UNC and lots of friendly rivalry.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: I attend on-line so I only know what my friends tell me. It is cold in the winter and hot in the summer.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Durham is a small town, but it actually has really great restaurants that are reasonably priced for what they offer. There are some boutiques in the Ninth Street area, but it's necessary to drive out to Southpoint to go to the movies or do other kinds of shopping. Also, some parts of the city can be quite dangerous, and it's not safe to go out alone at night anywhere off campus.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Transportation around campus is great, with shuttles running between campuses all the time. I had a car for all 4 years, but without one, it would be difficult getting around in Durham and the surrounding area. The airport is not too far, and it's easy to take a taxi to get there.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Durham is neither pretty or full of culture. As an undergraduate student I find it hard to do anything in Durham. It's not even like we have lots of natural resources in the area either. Furthermore, Durham is not a big fan of Duke-- we're polar opposites. Durham is lower to middle class, but Duke is full of elitist kids. They don't have a good perspective of us.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Duke's campus is absolutely gorgeous. You feel like you are walking back in time. All of the facilities are up to date and the campus is very accommodating. You can easily walk from West Campus to the Medical Campus through building and the transportation from West/Medical Campus to East Campus is very easy. Duke has some great athletic teams, fun events though the semester, great food throughout campus and nice old libraries.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Many people don't take advantage of the free Durham city bus, the Bull City Connector. It can take you all around downtown Durham and it is very convenient. Shuttles on campus are also free.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Parking is very difficult. You need at least 30 minutes to have enough time to park and get to your class on time. The best days are the days when you get a lucky spot in the closest parking lot!
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Weather is typically unpredictable, but I haven't dealt with extreme storms or weather conditions.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are always buses running between the campuses, and there's a mobile app to track when the next bus will be at which stop-which is really help for.  There is an awesome program that allows you to rent cars with prior reservations with relatively low cost, and the school is located within walking distance of several eateries and a mall.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Local AAA baseball team; tons of great restaurants; DPAC with lots of shows; good music scene; great state parks for outdoor activities
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Getting around campus is very easy and the transportation is free. It is also free to go to Chapel Hill. The problm lies in that if you dont have a car, it becomes very difficult to get around town and to venture off campus.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Bus is free in Durham.  So you can take it or drive and park outside your building.  If there is no parking, then there is usually a parking garage close by.  I have to park in the medical clinic building, which is right across from the nursing school.  Its an easy walk .
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: It's well known in the US as a top school.  The nursing school is the highest ranked individual school on its campus
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Coming from California's central coast I didn't expect much, but the weather is surprisingly nice. And from what I hear from my peers, it is much better than many other places you could be.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The transportation between the two main undergraduate campuses is easy to use, free and runs frequently. Waiting for a bus on the weekend may take up to twenty minutes though.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Durham is a good place. It has its dangerous parts, as any other college does. Police at Duke are constantly around. Not like overbearing figures but, you know, they're around in case things go down. The reason Durham gets bashed by college rankings in terms of safety in my opinion is because Duke actually REPORTS crimes rather than not as I've heard some colleges do.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: We get snow once a year or less. There are hurricanes to the East, earthquakes up North, and tornadoes more inland - but the daily weather is warm and dry. There are sudden downpours - carry an umbrella.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Durham has great food establishments, but does lack in cultural attractions.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The campus is beautiful - it looks like a castle.  The Bryan Center is a great place to study, and has a few good restaurants to grab food.  The Gym has wonderful facilities as well.  If you're religious, there's nothing better than going to a service in the Duke Chapel.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: As an engineer, I never have trouble finding a computer to work at. Most students have their own computers, but the students who don't have plenty of options to work on either a Mac or a PC. The Wifi network is one of the best I've used. If you're downloading 60Mb of data it only takes a couple of seconds, and it never gets bogged down when people are streaming music, movies, etc... In all my time at Duke, there was only one problem with the network, and it was fixed within a couple of minutes.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The campus itself is excellent and has amazing facilities.  Campus life is good, with plenty of clubs to join and weekly emails for grad student events.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: I like warm weather, so the hot and humid summers aren't a problem for me.  The winter gets cold, but not nearly as cold as more northern states and without much snow at all.  I absolutely love the autumn here.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: There are free buses that run between East and West campus all day and good portion of the night. There are enough buses so that they come around every 5 minutes, so you don't have to wait very long. If it get late enough in the night that you can't catch a buses, there is a number you can call to ensure your safety.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: I'm in the Pratt School of Engineering, and I'm a Biomedical Engineering major. Thus far, the classes have all been challenging, yet survivable. A good number of my instructors have a good sense of humor. They give very good advice when asked questions outside of class as well. They are always open to help you in anyway possible.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: All of the buildings on East and West campus are gorgeous and well-maintained. There are always construction projects going on to improve the quality/functionality of all of the buildings. The most important places on campus - i.e. the library, student centers, and dorms - have been or will be updated soon. Though some dorms are older, I've found them to be plenty spacious and clean. There are tons of great study spaces all over campus, and there's an abundance of spots to hang out with friends.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Duke has a bunch of different computer labs, and computers available to use. Get used to MacIntosh because this a very Apple-centric campus. The computers in the music building, Smith Warehouse, language labs, and multi-media studios are loaded with thousands of dollars of software that is free for all Duke students to use. Also, every time that there is a more up-to-date version of software, Duke makes it available for download for its students free of charge!
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Computers are usually available as many students have laptops. Printing on campus is hit or miss--printing stations (ePrints) are in most dorms and many academic buildings but often times aren't working, however, another one is always close by!
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Duke has great athletic facilities and libraries, as well as more social events than you could ever go to.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: weather is great, Im from the north east and its so warm! but in the spring you get wicked bad allergies because of all the pollen (just for like a month)
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Small City in Transition – Durham is a small city in transition. There are pockets of increasing urbanization/gentrification (like Brightleaf, the American Tobacco District, the Warehouse District), but there are also huge swaths of intense poverty. The yuppie Durham community seems pretty intent on either ignoring the problems facing lower-income residents or just advocating for more police presence, neither or which do much to build positive relationships among the entire town.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Durham weather can bring a gorgeous sunny day for three hours and then a thunderstorm. However, there is a relatively warm climate and beautiful foliage. It depends what you are used to.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Alumni Alumni ALUMNI – Duke has the most Amazing set of alumni you can possibly find. My freshman year I was offered a job that would have me set for life. With the professors, researchers, visiting recruiters, and established alumni who prefer hiring "Dukies", you've got a vital system set in place to help you succeed. There's such variety at Duke that you can find yourself ready and set for Law/Medical School, or you can take an offer as a computer systems analyst, or you can travel the world for archaeological digs. Duke's art/dance/music programs are also fantastic so don't think you're limited to the sciences and humanities.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: It's Just So Pretty – Many of the facilities are state-of-the-art, newly designed tools to enhance student life. For example, there are hubs of study rooms with walls of usable technology to help with learning. Also, the buildings are constantly updated while the previous decor is reinforced and maintained.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Busing . . Oh the Duke bus system . . . it's great that it's there and all, but during busy class time it can be pure madness.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: West Campus is beautiful, there's no doubt about it. If you live on west, you're living in literally a gothic wonderland and you're (usually) within 5 minutes from class, food, the gym and the bus stop. It's great - and East Campus (for freshmen) is nice because everyone is in the same boat.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Good and Happy, but Could Def Be Better – Computers are pretty much always available, but they are only Macs, which is frustrating when you are a PC. Actual desktops have better wireless connectivity than lap tops, but laptop connectivity is not slow- except for on Central, where it sometimes went out for a few minutes over the summer. E-prints available at many locations, but some out of the way, and many times they break. However, we pretty much get all-inclusive printing! Personal computers are definitely a plus, unless you want to live in the library (which is beautiful and cool, but still).
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Just Based on Price – I haven't started school yet so I can't speak to the availability of parking but at the price they charge I would be upset if I got there and was not able to find a spot. For graduate students to park by West Campus it is over $300 and I think it was per semester. I will be planning on riding the bus.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: If you want complete access, be prepared to by multiple permits. Sometimes, you won't be able to find a park on Central, because off campus students and faculty take them (they lie about being Central residents to avoid parking in the Blue Zone, which would sufficiently accommodate them).
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: The buses are the best way to travel from one campus to another. If you want to bike or walk, it's possible, but it's not for everyone. The campus was not built for thousands of students and faculty to drive around the campus during a normal day, so leave your vehicle at home until it's time to move out.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: As Duke has such a large campus, there is really no other option than  to take the buses. It's a hassle but you get used to it. They recently added a bunch of new, clean buses-- many of which are energy efficient.--- which is kind of cool.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review:
Duke has two major campuses: East and West.
East Campus houses all of the freshman and is modeled in Georgian architecture (red brick, etc.) It has its own library and union. West Campus is often called  a "Gothic Wonderland," absolutely beautiful. The cornerstone of the university is the Chapel which sits in the center of West Campus. Our student union is called the Bryan Center and has a nice walkway that people sit and lounge along on nice days. We have a great library system (make sure to check out "the link" if you visit) and top of the line athletic facilities.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Buses Are Good – There are buses that run every 5 minutes from west to east campus, which is super helpful for freshman!
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: Hot and Rainy – It can be very hot in the summer, but when it rains it monsoons.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: weather is warm and sunny and great to be outdoors
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: They Are Very Good – they are good. they are top level. i enjoy and use them.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: Academics and Sports – One thing I love about Duke is that it offers not only superb academic direction, leadership, and growth, but also offers an AMAZING basketball team that connects the entire student body in school spirit. It is one of a kind to find such an elite school that also excels in sports. At Duke, there is a great balance between academics and social life, and the vibrant sports life adds to that mix.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Duke University has amazing Wi-Fi connection and blazing fast internet speed. The entire campus has internet connection and never has bad service.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: Beautiful on the Outside – The Duke campus is really aesthetically pleasing, from the outside.  Most buildings are not quite as nice on the inside.  The student center (the Bryan Center) is awkwardly laid out with confusing, inconveniently placed stairs that lead to different floors.  Many classroom buildings have white walls reminiscent of a hospital.  There are not enough outlets in any of the classrooms.  Also, the inside of the Perkins Library is not nearly as nice as the outside.  Though East and West campuses are really pretty, Central Campus is rather ugly and sketchy looking.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Bus System Sucks – I hate the bus system here so I try choose my classes on West campus so I can avoid using the buses whatsoever.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The Best of Durham – The Durham area has a lot to offer Duke students, and our great relationship with the surrounding communities allows students several deals and opportunities to take advantage of all Durham has to offer. My favorite thing about Durham is the multitude of really awesome restaurants and diverse cuisines all across town. Additionally, Durham has a history of activism which has not ceased today. Durham is a proud community that partakes in several year round cultural events.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Campus is hands-down one of the most beautiful in the country. Architecture is gorgeous and plenty of greenery. Gym, library, student center are all new and filled with amazing amenities.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Fantastic architecture, gyms, dorms, libraries, and anything else. Truly a world class university.
Campus.Author: College Student

Campus.Review: NC has great weather. Its not too cold and not too hot. Plus, the Duke Gardens are beautiful year round, great to study or hangout
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Total Access – We have great wi fi access and speed. There are printers and computer labs all over campus with brand new mac computers. Most people have their own computer so the computer labs are open unless there is a random class. Our printing service is the best. We can print from our own laptops and then retrieve our print jobs with our swipe card from a kiosk. The printing cost is technically free!
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Buses com often in rush hours. But very few buses during breaks and weekends.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: A Foodie Place – Durham is a great little town.  There is plenty to do as far as things down town.  There are incredible restaurants that promote local and sustainable foods.  Every Sunday is a farmers market with local farmers selling anything from veggies to goat cheese.  Not more than 15 minutes away is the Eno River State Park that offers nice hikes and great trial runs.  Overall, a wonderful place to live and explore.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: North Carolina has very nice weather. Spring starts in February, so don't worry about a long winter. Of course we get cold days and rain but the spring and fall are both beautiful, warm and not too humid.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Like We Fell Out of a Movie – The most unique thing about this school that has continued to baffle me is that everyone in the school is fit. And I'm not talking about stick thin or 26-inch biceps, but I mean we're all healthy and generally conscientious about our health. And I don't know about any other school but I feel like it's a novel thing.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: You'll Never Get Bored – I gotta hand it to Duke, they really take care of their students well. I mean where do I start. You'd be a fool to think that they didn't have good athletic centers. I mean...it's Duke. That aside they have a bunch of places to study. The libraries are stocked with books and desk help. You can even get your electronics fixed in the Link (the students' electronics resource located in Perkins library). There is ALWAYS something going on in the school, from dances to pumpkin catapults to famous speakers. And the campus is also beautiful and has the Duke gardens so if you're tired of all of the academics, then you can just stroll in and get lost.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Beautiful on One Half, Quaint on the Other – West Campus is unrivaled - the Chapel, Perkins library, Wilson gym (that many varsity athletes use and a large portion of the student body as well), the quad, the Forest...East Campus is an older version. It has its own gym (Brodie) as well as music and dance buildings, and a library (Lily) but they are clearly older and have a different style of architecture.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: We have strong sports program, but also one of the highest rates of athletes actually graduating.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The campus is split into three campuses: West, East, and Central. Buses go between them. The buses are good, except right between classes when hundreds of people crowd to get on. A few people have bikes. Cars are useful, but very few freshmen have/need them. There are some other buses that go into the city, and to Chapel Hill.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: So Much to Do – There are lots of good restaurants near to campus. If you have a car, it's easy to get around and find good shopping places. Sports are big here. There's much more activity directly related to Duke (i.e. put on by Duke students) than anything done by Durham.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Parking is great, but expensive. You don't really need a car.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Bus rocks – The bus system provided by duke is AWESOME! C1 really helps a lot. But there're certainly some place that buses don't cover, like Hull studio where students dance classes and is ten-minute walk from bus stop.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Not bad, but not as excited as you might imagine – Growing up in a big city, I was totally disappointed for the first semester at duke. There's not much to do after class at night other than hanging out with friends at dorm or going to parties. Off-campus party, seriously, is not at all safe. Even some on-campus parties will accidentally have some people outside come in.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Excellent Computer Lab – All big-screen apple computer and very accessible in east campus
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Parking sucks and the buses get really annoying- but they do their best to try to accomodate you. There is free transportation pretty much anywhere in Durham and they just bought new, bigger buses to make going back and forth from East/West easier.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The Blue Zone Is Stupid – East and central campus have great parking, but living on west (which is most convenient) also comes with the worst parking. On game days people have to move their cars and finding a good spot in the first lot is almost impossible.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: The gyms and athletic facilities here are great, and the libraries and various areas for studying are good as well.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Durham is really cool. It has lots of independently owned shops and the DPAC is cool too.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The weather here is bipolar, but there isn't really an effect on campus life.  Just make sure you bring a jacket with you in case it decided to cool off.  Also, bring rain boots because it rains a lot.  It doesn't snow much, which is the weather that could potentially affect campus life the most.  When it snows, it's usually an inch-ish...if that.  The weather is usually really nice...the summer can get VERY hot, but most students don't have to worry about that.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Awesome Athletics/School Spirit AND Extremely Ambitious Student Body – Makes for kind of a competitive combo, but never a dull moment.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: Need a Car – If you want to survive at Duke, you need a car. The campus becomes a bubble, so you will need to get out every now and then.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: There are tons of computers available and there is no need to get a printer on campus. The only exception is during exam time; be prepared to have to wait in line to print your essay or find a printer out of reach that is not broken. A lot of computers start going down during exam time.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Duke students undoubtedly boost the surrounding economy of Durham, North Carolina. However, many students do not have cars at Duke, so better transportation needs to be provided for students enjoy all that Durham has to offer.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Freshman year is the best as far as parking goes. However on main campus, parking is horrible. The parking lot for majority of students is a good walk away from main classes.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Eprint Is the Best – Duke offers plently of computers, scanners, and printers.  There are easy to access and don't cost extra.  The only thing that costs extra is color printing and copying, which can be frustrating at times.  A laptop is almost a necessity, especially for engineers.  Some students have their own printers, but this is not necessary at all.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Wilson Gym on West Campus has tons of equipment and space.  The libraries on West are spacious, comfortable, and great for studying and writing papers.  Brodie Gym on East Campus is a bit small, but otherwise very user-friendly.  Lilly Library on East Campus is a bit dreary and hard to work in.  Both campuses have great buildings, layouts, and are gorgeous.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: There are four seasons. It is cold in the winter but then gets nice in the spring. Monsoon season is pretty annoying because you can get caught in a shower at any time in the spring, but the rain usually goes away pretty quickly.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: The Bryan Center is the student center; it houses a cafe, several restaurants, the lobby shop where you can purchase food/other items without having to go to a grocery store, the university textbook store, the on-campus bookstore, the computer store, a movie theater, an auditorium, and other rooms where organizations can meet such as Greek life. Cameron stadium is the basketball court, which is near Wilson Gym, a gym that offers everything a student needs to stay fit and healthy. Perkins Library is where most students spend their evenings and offers four floors of areas to study. It is also connected to Bostock Library, another popular place to study.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Terrible bus system – On an average day, I spend at least an hour waiting for or riding on buses to get between campuses. Duke has West campus (the main campus), East (where freshmen live), and Central (apartments for upperclassmen). Budget cuts have made the buses run less frequently, and when they do they are overcrowded to the point where a simple bus ride can be a miserable experience.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Durham Food – That's the majority of the attraction of Durham to Duke students- the various restaurants. There are probably lots of cultural events, and other things to do, but most Duke students don't leave the bubble that is Duke unless it's to go to area nightclubs.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: From friends' stories about other campuses, Duke has a comparatively good parking system. It is confusing, and there are a lot of tickets given out for being one or two spaces away from the "correct" area, even when the spaces aren't marked, but for the most part it is not too much of a hassle to park. Having a car doesn't help much get between campuses, unfortunately, since the bus system is literally the most agonizing part about Duke.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Mild, Can't Complain – There isn't air conditioning in a lot of dorms, so when it's hot, it's very very hot. When it's cold outside, though, it's still hot inside because they crank up the heat and there's no way to turn it down.
Campus.Author: College Freshman

Campus.Review: Campus Life – Duke combines academics and sports very well.  You have so many opportunities and so many options it confuses you at times. We are really passionate about sports so make sure you are ready for that because we are CHAMPIONS!!!
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Duke has its own transportation system that is free.  The buses go through all three campus.  Due to budget cuts they have reduced the the number of buses but even then you can walk to West Campus.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Computer labs are everywhere!!! Wifi is great!!! You really don't need a laptop unless you like to type your notes. Everything is through the network so you can print directly from your laptop.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Neither Great Nor Bad – permits are very expensive - $250 for the year. parking is a bit of a walk, but that preserves the beauty of west campus. a pain to move your car on football game days
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: There is lots to do and see with high profile students and faculty.  The work is challenging but the presentations are great and the location is prime.  Visit Raleigh or Chapel Hill (both are neighboring cities).  Watch high class NCAA basketball.
Campus.Author: College Senior

Campus.Review: It's Pretty Convenient – It can be a pain at times though. They stop running C1's on weekends and after 8 on weekdays now, so it can take 15 minutes for a bus to come and another 15 minutes for the bus to take you between east and west campus
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Printing is usually convenient. Every once in a while a printer will be jammed or you won't have a printer nearby. Computers are fine. Good internet access
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Everyone here says that we have the best of both worlds, and we really do. There's great academics, but also an incredible social scene. While people say that Dukies are arrogant or cocky because of this attitude, the facts cannot be denied.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Duke does a really good job of keeping their stuff up to date and clean. The athletic facilities are akin to those of a country club, and campus is just beautiful in general.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Buses Rule the School – Duke is a split campus and therefore heavily relies on buses to move students to and from both campuses. Therefore Duke transportation has it down pretty much to an art. Buses arrive quite frequently and are easy to use
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: They Love Giving Tickets – Parking on east is much easier than parking on west. However the campus police LOVE giving tickets so make sure that you have the right permit for where your parking or you're most likely going to come back to a ticket. Cars on campus are really not necessary. Even though Duke is a split campus there are buses running regularly, and East Campus is within walking distance of all attractions in downtown Durham.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: No top tier university can boast an athletic program like Duke's.  Two Division One basketball championships inside of a decade along with a bevy of golf, tennis and now lacrosse titles.  The campus goes wild during basketball season; it seems everyone is a rabid fan.  Students have camped out for 8 WEEKS to get front row tickets to some of these nationally televised games.  And don't you dare wear light blue any time close to a Duke-North Carolina game; people will stare daggers at you!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Bring Rainboots – Going to school in the South means sunshine and shorts well into November.  Be prepared for some serious humidity the first four weeks of school, however!  Duke gets maybe three snowstorms a year and then completely shuts down the following day.  I am from Colorado and I find this absolutley hilarious.  We do get plenty of moisture though..
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Sort of Lame – Parking for juniors on Central Campus apartments is pretty much the best parking the school has to offer. Freshman parking is limited but still better than parking on West campus. I think the price for a parking permit is undeserved because the lots are so far away from the dorms, particularly on West, and cars must be moved during football games.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Great Opportunities and Lots of Fun – Durham is a very cool city, especially since renovations and upgrades have begun. However, there is still some speculation among students as to whether or not their safety will be upheld, and this fear is intensified each time there is talk of a robbery near campus. Overall, though, Duke itself is a very safe place to live with a gorgeous campus and much to do by day and night. The diversity of the city and campus makes Duke an excellent place to attend the local cultural events. Besides Durham, both Chapel Hill and Raleigh are nearby and provide excellent entertainment and shopping. The Durham Performing Arts Center and the Durham Bulls baseball park are really great as well.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Above Average – I've never felt like I really was underserved by any of the facilities on campus, except maybe the lack of an on-campus grocery for basic fresh food products. The gym is sufficient, though not extensive. The dining options are seemingly broad. The student union keeps most of what I need in the same place (school supplies, post office, smoothies, posters, theaters). The library is open at all hours of the day and night, practically (and literally during exam periods). So, though not excellent in every regard, Duke's facilities are above sufficient. And the campus is beautiful!
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: The students at Duke are fun but also hardworking. You're in a nice environment where everyone wants to help each other succeed and isn't really cut-throat at all. The campus is extremely beautiful and offers lots of opportunities for students to pursue their interests through clubs and sports. The school spirit is great with our basketball team, making tenting one of the most memorable college experiences you will have.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Not Crowded, Great Printing System – The computer lab in my dorm was never full, but the computers were a little outdated. I never saw the library computer labs full. Most people have a laptop and use library computers for their software. The wireless internet is great and rarely had any downtime. e-Print is fantastic and there is no need for a personal printer.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: All Four Seasons – Rain in the spring, cold in the winter, hot and humid in the summer, but never outrageous and often beautiful.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Terrible: hard to find spots and expensive. Vigilant police force writes a lot of tickets, although appeal committee is lenient.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Transportation is generally good. Despite the fact that East Campus is isolated from West Campus, there are always free buses available running between the two campuses. On weekends and at nights, the East-West bus (the C-1) only runs every 20 minutes, but once you learn the schedule it's not too bad. During breaks, Duke also runs free shuttles to and from the airport.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Convenient Buses – Very convenient (though sometimes crowded) free buses run by Duke make getting around easier. And the Robertson to UNC is a great way to get out of Durham for shopping/eating out.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: In general, the facilities at Duke are really good. Especially on West Campus, the gym (Wilson), the library (Perkins and Bostock), and the student center (Bryan Center), are clean, up-to-date, and convenient. The facilities on East Campus are a little more dated and smaller but still above average.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: My situation is a little different because the nursing program has its own computer lab.  They are fast, and there are usually plenty available.  We are allotted a generous amount of printing, which is included in our tuition.  The computers in the main library on campus are readily available, but I have noticed that printing is not and it can be a hassle.
Campus.Author: Recent Alumnus

Campus.Review: Though I haven't taken advantage of it yet, Duke Engage is a very popular way to make the most out of your undergraduate experience here by having a trip to take part in something that is meaningful to both you and a greater community funded by the university.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Perfect Southern weather. Although summers can get a little hot, the general weather is appreciable. The Duke Gardens will be a perfect place for students to hang out, relax, or even study at when fall or spring hits.
Campus.Author: College Junior

Campus.Review: Durham, NC – Durham is a very bipolar community. On the main streets the city is fantastic. The eateries are plentiful and range from exquisite to commonplace. However, there are some very, very dangerous parts of Durham, so a Duke student quickly learns to be vigilant.
Campus.Author: College Sophomore

Campus.Review: Duke has a great system of buses traveling between campuses, and is currently working towards improving bus schedules to meet the needs of students more efficiently. Bus locations are convenient and at no cost.
Campus.Author: College Student

Value.Review: Most students are hired for good jobs or accepted into grad school by graduation.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: IF you start looking in your senior year, you are pretty likely to get a job after graduation. But of course, there are some people who dont. sometimes its hard because you have to had an internship, done research, or have done a million other things. That's really hard to accomplish in your four years.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Duke is one of the most prestigious schools in the country and world. A Duke degree can go a long way.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: To me, the value of a Duke degree comes from the people you meet while you are a student here. Research positions are relatively easy to find, even if you have to travel 10 minutes off campus to Research Triangle Park. Also, since there are so many positions in research and academia around Durham, several alumni stay in the area, and they are willing to hire Duke students to help them.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I feel happy with my choice to attend this school.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I do alumni fundraising and it seems like almost all the alumni I call are doing really well. The degree definitely has great value, particularly for finance/econ type careers
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: A Duke degree = a good job or grad school
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: I know the career center is there to help students no matter what.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: A Duke degree is a dream to many people, including myself. I know that it will take me so far, even to places I know I do not belong. When I got here is when I realized that school is not a competition. I realized that I was where I needed to be when I met people and became friends with people that were way smarter than I am. Every day is a challenge, but getting that degree is so worth it.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I feel that a degree from this school means that you know not only OF a subject or ABOUT a subject. You actually know THE subject; you've not only been taught the inner workings and concepts of it, but also how to produce new theories and pieces of knowledge within the subject area yourself. Duke trains you with research, internships, and hands-on opportunities that allow you to raise your questions and find the answers to them. That, in my opinion, is an in-depth way of learning.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: The prestige definitely helps a lot. I was able to get a job immediately after graduation and have now been accepted to multiple master's and doctoral programs for the next step in my career. The career center also helps match students with internships, fellowships, jobs, etc.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Though it hasn't happened to me yet (ugh), people seem successful in getting what they're after, or at least figuring it out.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Everyone I've interviewed with wants Duke grads. Makes the job search process easy.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: I haven't yet utilized the career center, but my hope is that the degree from a prestigious school like Duke will offer some unique job opportunities to me after graduation.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Having a duke degree basically guarantees you a job, just because of the prestige that surrounds it. Lots of opportunities for internships and the career center is very helpful.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Having a relevant degree from Duke has a great impact on career/internship/medical school options. The baseline at Duke is much higher than the baseline for other schools.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: The alumni network is fantastic, and there is already a variety of people that current students can reach out to and ask questions. The career center is also a helpful resource, and Duke also seems to be a hotspot for career recruitments.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Duke really tries to work with you to get the most possible financial aid as needed.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Duke is very expensive and my family has just the right amount of money that we can neither pay for it without financial aid and yet we are screwed and I don't receive very much aid at all.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Merit scholarships are rare, but financial aid is accommodating and understanding.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: School is expensive and the aid seems to be a secret formula.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Duke's stature is rivaled only by a handful of universities across the world. A degree from this institution insists upon its holder's merits, accountability, and scholarly disposition. Summer jobs and internships abound at coveted organizations in every field -- finance, medicine, engineering, arts, policy, you name it. One of the university's leading assets is its alumni network, which has been carefully cultivated over many decades. Former students look back fondly on their experiences here and, when considering prospects, are very often predisposed to turn to their alma mater. I have not yet consulted with the career center, but friends and colleagues have spoken favorably of it.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I don't really have much experience with financial aid or scholarships. I do know that MANY students graduate in debt - it's a pricey school. Also, because so so SO many people are so qualified/smart, it seems virtually impossible to earn a merit scholarship, and if you do it's by chance.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Getting it, I don't know, but options for work study aren't great
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Just fill out the FAFSA. Students are automatically considered for scholarships.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I did not receive much financial aid from the university.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: I did not get the financial aid I applied for but I will try again next year
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: There are no complaints with the quality of the education. The ranking of the university is reflected in the opportunities and services available to the students, in addition to the professors and courses.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: There are a lot of forms to fill out, but I got a $12k scholarship I didn't even have to apply for, which was nice.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Duke is stingy. So many people reject coz they can't afford it
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Of course, more fin aid would have been welcome. Wouldn't say I received all the fin aid I needed but what I received definitely helps.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: For the graduate program I am in there are standard scholarships everyone gets which is nice, but makes it difficult to get additional aid.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I received a very generous merit-based scholarship
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Bad. Very bad. Very stingy.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: If you need aid, you will most likely receive it.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: If parents make less than tuition. tuition is essentially free if your grades are to standard.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: There just aren't many scholarship opportunities in my field, therefore, it is nearly impossible to get one.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Be honest, and let them know everything about you.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: They are extremely generous and give 100% of need-based aid. Totally helpful!
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Like every school of its calibar, they meet "need".  Which means that Duke will ask for every penny the FAFSA says that the family can afford.  It screws middle class families over.  If you are rich, 50k isn't bad.  If you are poor, they'll cover every penny.   If you make 80k a year?  They'll happily take 20k of that, thank you very much.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: There are a couple of merit scholarships which are dope if you get them. Otherwise, it's all FA.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: My parents didn't think I would get financial aid from anywhere, because we are upper middle class. I didn't even apply for it until way after the deadline passed, but we got a good amount of financial aid anyway.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: have always been able to reach someone when needed
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: The financial aid department was extremely helpful and willing to walk me through various forms etc.  However, I found there wasn't as much non-federal aid, such as scholarships or grants available as I had anticipated.  I suggest looking for other resources outside of the school for financial assistance.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: I received a good amount of aid, including grants, which cut down on the debt. I graduated with around $20k in student loans, and the aid office was always available for questions. The only thing I would recommend for improvement is to try to allow students to graduate debt-free.
Value.Author: Recent Alumnus

Value.Review: Financial aid is a pretty difficult thing to assess in my opinion. I got a lot of aid as a freshman. Now as a sophomore, I've had to take out a couple grand in loans and I was lucky to land a scholarship to cover some of it. Hope it only gets better from here but I doubt it.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Financial aid office has been very helpful with filling out forms and answering questions.  Scholarships are fair and mostly need based so everyone should apply
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review:
Duke is a private school. So for someone who is in the middle class, you get virtually no financial aid other than a little bit of work study. 
However, if you are in a situation where your family strongly shows a need for financial aid, the financial aid office will do there best to figure something out. Also, the financial aid office is open to fixing any mistakes that may show on your bursar bill.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Financial aid is  amazing! I come from a lower socio-economic background, and my family has to come out of their pockets with very little. The merit-scholarships are all full-ride for 4 years, but are extremely competitive. When filling out the FAFSA, I definitely recommend having someone professional help you.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Not Much for Grad Students – I was hoping to get a decent amount of financial support so I would not need a bunch of student loans to cover the cost but the bulk of my financial aid is student loans. They weren't very much help either when I contacted the financial aid office so when I get to school I may go try talking to Student Services. At my undergrad they were the ones who were the most helpful for getting financial aid, this school may turn out to be the same way. So I am stuck spending a lot of time looking for outside sources of funding.
Value.Author: College Junior

Value.Review: Duke determines financial aid ability based on how much money your parents make. They do a great job at meeting your demonstrated need--getting financial aid is easy; it's just a matter of completing Fafsa and the CSS Profile.
Value.Author: College Senior

Value.Review: Be Proactive – Make sure to get your forms in on time and be persistent because financial aid can be an issue at Duke. The office always quickly emails back and pretty good about communicating but they tend to be reluctant to just give away money, but if you make efforts and its doable
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Not Very Many Offered – There just aren't that many. The ones that we do have offer A LOT of money though (full rides or near full rides)
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Not Enough Aid – Duke does not offer any merit scholarships.  They give limited financial aid and almost every student is given work-study as a part of their package, which can be very ahrd to manage with the academic demands of Duke.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Need More! We lost a lot of varsity recruits because the financial aid wasn't enough without an athletic scholarship. I got almost no financial aid and its really straining my family.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: Normal Process – It's relatively well known that a fair portion of the students at Duke are economically relatively well off. But for those who are not included in that, Duke provides good financial aid to most. I received the financial aid I needed after filling out standard forms like FAFSA and CSS profile. There's no need to make in-person appointments, but if there are any questions, it's not too hard to call and ask the office.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: It's need-based, so if you have real need, you can definitely get it, but if you're in the in-between it's hard. I think like 60% or more kids are on some aid.
Value.Author: College Sophomore

Value.Review: Something I didn't realize until after I received my financial aid package is that if your family annual income is under $50,000, there is no parental contribution! Unfortunately, the student contribution is based on your reported earnings, so part-time jobs actually end up hurting you. I can't get a paid job for the next four years without increasing my student contribution.
Value.Author: College Freshman

Value.Review: I applied through FAFSA. The school gave me what I needed and whenever I need help with anything or have questions they are very helpful and answer my questions right away.
Value.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Off-campus dining is great!! Downtown Durham has so many options and a ton of variety that there is always something new to try.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Generally, after freshman year meals plans and options are great. Although it's nice that as freshman you can use your swipes and the Freeman Center instead of Marketplace. But it's horrible that you don't get that many food points to start with and you can only really eat in one place everyday. Also you have to miss two meals if you want brunch and dinner on weekends. After freshmen year you can have any meal plan size you want and there are tons of food options to select from. The only comment I really have with Duke Dinning, is that beyond Divinity there aren't that many healthy food options, and Divinity is no longer open for dinner.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Durham was rated one of the "foodiest cities in America"
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I would give it 5 stars, but MP takes it down 2 stars.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Durham food is one of my favorite parts of going to Duke. There are so many delicious options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Very, very poor and limited options.  As someone who enjoys exercising and eating large meals, I cannot spend less than $15 other than at McDonalds.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Durham has a number of unique options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: With my class schedule the options are very limited.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: lots of good food on 9th street
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I love Durham food. Huge part of my college experience
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: A lot of different restaurants close by. Fairly expensive, but many deliver on food points.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The dining options in Durham are absolutely amazing. There is such a wide variety of high quality and affordable restaurants in the area, and it's always fun getting off campus to try a new restaurant.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: As with most schools, the food is overpriced and mediocre.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: At the moment, the principal dining venue on West Campus is undergoing extensive renovations, so on-campus dining options are not as abundant as they once were (and will be upon the new structure's completion). However, the university has responded by bringing a number of food trucks to campus on weekdays; in my opinion, they collectively offer more diverse dining options than were previously available.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Campus dining is not really the best, especially for freshman. The freshman dining hall is not adequate for late night options, or even having variety on a day to day basis.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Durham is considered the foodiest town in the USA, so there are a plethora of off campus dining options.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review:
Freshman have the Marketplace, which is buffet style for breakfast and dinner. They have 5 stations that stay the same every day (pizza, pasta, stir fry, hamburgers/hotdogs/grilled chicken, and a salad bar) and one station that changes every day. However, it gets so boring and repetitive by the winter.

Dining on west is great.The Loop is my favorite and everything is practically in the Bryan Center. On central there is only Food Fac, but it's great. You can buy drinks (non-alcoholic and alcoholic) and snacks on food points there too.

Food points come in many different plans. Freshman get "swipes" to use at the Marketplace and around 400 food points. Sophomores and up can choose a plan with 1700-3000 points and more can always be added very easily.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Durham is known for it's variety in restaurants. And the food truck rodeo is great!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are a decent amount of food-options. Over the years it has gotten worse (especially with the construction).
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: It doesn't tastes good. at all. They all taste like paper. By the end of the year, I seldom use my food points as I spent most of my time eating off-campus.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: It sucks, there isn't much option. Sure Durham is a foodie town, but so far it's just restaurants after restaurants selling different varieties of sandwiches. It's good for the first one or two months, but after awhile, you'll get bored. Even the food options in Chapel Hill or Raleigh wouldn't be enough, but then again I eat out almost everyday.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I'm a vegan, and the healthy options are great! You really have to get out there and look for things... hit up Monuts Donuts, Mad Hatters, Whole Foods, Pops, WaDuke, Elmos, Fosters, Parker and Otis, and Guglhupf!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Durham is truly a great place to find anything to eat! There are a number of upper-end restaurants that students occasionally eat at, but most of the students are found eating on Ninth Street or on Erwin Road. Still, if you want to explore the dining options, you will find a variety of appealing, affordable options. Favorites include Pizza Mia, Don Marcelo's, and La Vaquita.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Great options. Good variety of healthy things to choose from as well.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Durham is said to be the south's "tastiest town" and so far that seems to be right with lots of options and variety. Tere are many places I havent gotten to yet!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Durham was recently ranked the "foodiest" town in the south. The city surrounding Duke provides a plethora of off-campus dining options, the majority of which are affordable and delicious. On Sunday morning, you have to pile in the car and head to Monuts in downtown for a bagel sandwich and a fancy donut or two.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: It's pretty good. Durham was awarded for its food.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: There are good restaurants close by
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Foodiest town in the South speaks for itself!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are much more places to dine in Durham if you have a car, and if you do the possibilities are endless! Durham is named one of the best cities for food in America and they are right. It is delicious and there is much to choose from! But not so much walking distance as driving distance...
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: As I previously mention dinning in durham is awesome.
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: I am not a huge Duke dining fan.  Most people eat at ABP, the Loop, or Grace's.  Freshman meal plan is absurd.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Durham was ranked the Foodiest Town in America a couple years ago.  Farmer's markets within walking distance of campus, and 9th Street and Erwin have a healthy mix of chains (Noodles and Co., Chipotle, etc.) and local options (Sushi Love, Mad Hatter's, Chubby's Tacos).
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Doing tons of construction now so it's very inconvenient and limited, but it should improve in two years. The food is good but expensive. Variety is unfortunately hard to come by.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Durham was rated the best city in the US for food recently by Southern Living and another publication. Huge into sustainable food supply, local farming, and organic foods. The variety of cuisines is significant, and the quality is high. Durham offers a slew of breweries, cheap restaurants, nice restaurants, and late-night food options (especially close to campus). A true foodie's city.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: It's good, but you get sick of it. And the meal plan is very confusing at first, but you'll get the hang of it after a while.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Great options to eat on campus. We have over 30 eateries and then also a rotating food truck schedule which is awesome (crepe truck, dumpling truck, taco truck, etc). 2 of the campus restaurants are open 24 hours. There is also merchants-on-points where you can order food from local restaurants that will deliver to campus and you pay with food points! Also we got Red Mango this year which is new and delicious!
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The food is nothing special. Be careful at night.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Mexican, Chinese, Thai, French, Japanese
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: On campus food service provide a good variety of food choices
Food.Author: Recent Alumnus

Food.Review: great food, but current construction limits selection
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: There are plenty of restaurant options, lots of breweries and fun atmospheres to go and hang out.  Other cities nearby like Raleigh and Chapel Hill add variety to the list of restaurants.  Cost overall is fairly inexpensive.  The public transit makes most places accessible without a vehicle, but I recommend having a car to explore surrounding areas and the restaurants there.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Off-campus dining at Duke is great! There are a wide variety of dining options on Ninth street two blocks away from the freshmen campus, in Brightleaf downtown, and in the Tobacco warehouse district downtown as well. And if you have the transportation, you can also enjoy all of the restaurants in the Chapel Hill area especially along Franklin street. Just in the triangle area, you can explore a world of culinary tastes, from Italian to Ethiopian to Peruvian. There are also a number of chains located close to the main campus.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: I have not explored the vast array of off-campus dinning that is available, but the few places I have been to are wonderful.  Cost; you can find a place to get good food on any budget.  The diversity of food is endless.  Basically, the options are plentiful and delicious.  I recommend Tobacco Road because I love their mac n cheese and you can watch any sport you want.  I also recommend Parker and Otis for brunch because its a cute shop with low cost, very good food.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: The freshman meal plan is a little ridiculous but the food in the dining hall on East is good and has a lot of variety.  After freshman year, the only option you have is food points, which can be spent at all the food venues on campus and other off-campus places that deliver to the Duke campus.  Sometimes it seems there aren't a lot of options but if you actively try to go to a variety of places then it's doable.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Campus food is being renovated. Food is decent but becomes trite. There are many options, which is nice, and the basics are all covered. There are good options for take out and delivery and Durham as a city is known for its great food if you get tired of eating on campus!
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Great choices if you're looking to mix it up. Durham is known for it's food choices. Many places are within walking distance and can be relatively cheap. Downside is if you have a big food points plan, you may eat off campus less.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: There's a lot of different off-campus options on 9th street that is easily walking distance from Duke. There's the famous Dame's Chicken and Waffles as well as different good cafes and restaurants.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: If you're a fan of southern food, you'll love it.  I haven't found a ton of places I like, but the brightleaf area, tobacco district, and 9th street are fun places to go.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Durham has been rated among the best small cities for food, and lives up to that reputation. There are a ton of great restaurants right off of campus, many offering discounts to Duke students. Not to mention there is a Whole Foods, Sushi Love, Noodles, and Chipotle across the street from campus.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: There are two main campuses that you will spend time on - East and West. East campus houses all of the freshmen and has only one place to eat called The Marketplace. The Marketplace has great breakfast and brunch, but some people complain that the dinner gets old. On West campus, however, there are so many great places to eat that the food never gets old. There is the great hall which offers a la carte food, then restaurants like Au Bon Pain, Chick Fil-A, Alpine Bagels, The Loop (pizza and grill), and more. Not to mention the Divinity and Law School refectories are God's gift to this earth.
Food.Author: College Sophomore
