Food.Review: Few Healthy Options, Many Delicious Choices – There's great food scattered all around East, West and Central Campuses - the only caveat is that it's hard to come by healthy stuff. A lot of students resort to eating McDonald's, Chik-fil-A or Armadillo Cafe pretty frequently.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Dining is Awesome!! There are over 30 on-campus eateries. But that's not it! Duke has an ongoing agreement with some of the local off-campus restaurants. The program is called "Merchants on Points" and you can use your allotted food plan to order food from different restaurants (they even deliver)!
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: East Campus Repetitive West Campus Good – The Marketplace on East Campus gets repetitive but the rest of food on campus is awesome!
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Food Is Good Depending on Where You Live – If you live on East...food options are limited, especially late at night, partially because the dining plan is restricting...but West and Central offer a lot of food options...and then there are Merchants on Points, local vendors that accept food points as payment...you will have options...side note...always take the highest food plan that your financial aid allows for...sounds obvious but I didn't do it freshman year and I was screwed.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: The food options are limited, especially during freshman year. The food is good, but there aren't enough vegan/vegetarian options. Everything eventually gets old, so it's nice to be able to cook, if you live off campus or on Central.
Food.Author: College Senior

Food.Review: Off Campus Is Inconvenient – Going off campus to eat is really inconvenient.  9th street, right off of East Campus has some decent eateries (Elmo's Diner is great), but going late at night is sketchy if you're not with a large group.  Unless you have a car, it's really not easy to eat off campus.  Several places offer "merchants on points" delivery, which allows you to use your meal plan "points" to pay for food, but they can get pricey if you're not into pizza or chinese food.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Durham Munch – There are plenty of restaurants around campus. Cost, convenience, and variety are fantastic. Sushi Love is a great place for a warm meal.
Food.Author: College Student

Food.Review: Good but Expensive – There is a large variety of campus eateries unlike some other universities; however, most places are expensive and the cheap food is unhealthy.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Great Food Off Campus – There's a ton of local restaurants from Mexican to Thai that's within walking distance.  Or you can call deliver and pay for it using food points (Merchants on Points). However, it can be expensive.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Not Bad... Just Expensive – The food is pretty good on campus if you can find it but the dining plan isn't very good especially if you're a freshman.  They make you buy a dining plan and get food points so you have 7 swipes a week for dinner/brunch on the weekend and then swipes for breakfast but you have to use food points for lunch. It's really confusing and sort of limits your choices. Also the food gets repetitive and isn't always the healthiest.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Marketplace sucks, as everyone knows. There aren't too many dining options on campus.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: The food is pretty good- you get pretty sick of Marketplace on East, but there are a lot of great places to eat on West. You will definitely run out of food points, so be prepared to buy more.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review:
Freshman Eating Options – There is a string of restaurants that are within a 5-10 minutes walk from the freshman dorms. So it is very easy to find a place to eat off campus. For non-vegetarians, Bali Hai is a pretty good and cheap place to go eat. As long as you learn how to stack your food, you can potentially get as much as you care to eat.
There are also several places within a 5-10 minutes diving distance. If you like real Chinese food, Li Ming's is a good place to go. Li Ming's is also an asian supermarket, so you could buy to fulfill all your asian food needs.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: Most of the Restaurants Are Off East Campus – There is a center call Brightleaf Square that has a number of restaurants; most are a little more on the expensive end, but not too bad.  We also have" merchants on points", which are restaurants near campus that will deliver and you can use your food points!  Many freshmen go to Cosmic Cantina for late night Mexican, and also Torrero's during the day.  9th Street and downtown (both closer to east than west campus) have some good options, but there are also some good restaurants on Erwin Road (right near west campus).
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Triangle Excellence ... If You Have a Car – The triangle area has so many great food options, however you need a car to access most of them. I have tried biking around campus and it can be dangerous because drivers are not used to bikers down there. However, do not let it stop you from hiking it to chapel hill. There is amazing food down here.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Off campus dining is fairly convenient as there are many restaurants or fast food locations with 2 miles of the campus. Prices range from very cheap to moderately expensive but the type of food is appropriate for its given price.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: The freshmen dining plan is subpar but is part of the first-year life on campus. They have their own campus as well as their own dining hall. Upper classmen have a much better dining plan and are designated food points as food dollars. These food points can be utilized anywhere on campus at a variety of different venues. It's sometimes hard to manage these points as they can be spent quickly, however its overall a successful and enjoyable program.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Ok but Need a Car – Once you get off campus, the food is actually quite good. They have this new program where you can get new discounts. A student favorite (for Sake Bombing if you're over) is Sushi Love. For freshmen living on East, Brightleaf is within walking distance.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Theoretically Great – Though there was clearly a lot of consideration put into dining at Duke, in my experience, it never turns out quite as good as it looks. There are a good number of options for those who live on West campus, but Central and East are pretty lacking in variety. There aren't many inexpensive food opportunities, either.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review:
The Duke freshman dining plan is pretty terrible and also complicated. It's a guarantee you will run out of food points and need to buy more. 
 However, sophomore year and up the plan is far better and there are a lot of options for eating. 

The food itself is pretty good. Sometimes it gets repetitive, but on the whole Duke does a good job. Also, to note, I'm a vegetarian and there seem to be plenty of options.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Food.Review: I Like to Eat...A Lot – Off East Campus (within walking distance) is Ninth Street and Brightleaf Square with many really good restaurants.  Definitely check it out.  You can also drive to Southpoint Mall where there is a Cheesecake Factory.  A local place called Local Yogurt also has good froyo.
Food.Author: College Junior

Food.Review: Wonderful and Varied Options – Duke has wonderful and varied options for dining on campus. The freshman dining hall provides a welcoming atmosphere that is shared with fellow classmates, and though the food is not top-quality the all-you-can-eat buffet-style makes up for it. Upperclassman options on West are incredible, including both eco-friendly eateries using locally grown ingredients and the favorite McDonalds, high-quality sit-down restaurants and quick hot dog stands.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Options=West Campus – West campus has many food options, all of them varied and reasonably priced. The Refectory provides a delicious brunch option, while the Blue Express provides great home cooked meals. However, the Marketplace, the only dining hall on east, doesn't have the best quality of meals. Plus, all freshman are required to purchase a dining plan which forces students to eat dinner there almost every night of the week. This proves troublesome when students are required to stay on West, since it is the hub of campus activities. Therefore, a night spent eating on West due to a club meeting, studying, or a concert means students are literally throwing away $14--the, overpriced, cost of dinner at the marketplace. Besides this one issue campus dining is overall satisfying.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Diverse but Expensive – Nearby we have ethnic cuisine of all kinds and great markets like Whole Foods. However, without lower end more practical markets, keeping in budget is a little difficult. Places like Brightleaf Square are over rated and expensive. Finding the best that Durham has to offer probably takes you off the well trodden path a bit.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: Freshman Meal Plan – Not a fantastic system. The Marketplace, the dining hall for freshmen, offers generally subpar food. There are quite a few restaurants to choose from, but as a freshman your meal points are fairly sparse and don't offer much in the way of flexibility before having to refill.
Food.Author: College Sophomore

Food.Review: While Ninth Street and Brightleaf Square nearby offer restaurants, there are only two or three decent places and none can be rated as amazing. Bali Hai, Mt. Fuji, and Cinelli's.
Food.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: A lot of dorms are far away from classes because of the different campuses, but generally they are nice and fairly spacious. Some used to not have air conditioning, but thats mostly been fixed.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: We have a lot of great new places to live. But there are also some pretty bad places that are really small. Depending on where you live you might be far from your classes.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Some of the Housing is great and others are mediocre. It depends on where you are on campus and the building. Some are close to classes and others are far. The lottery is fair to all.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: There is a definite hierarchy to which dorms students prefer. Some living spaces are brand new and look like a spaceship, while others have been around since the 1950s, and look like it. I would prefer it if housing selection was more about the people you are with, and the building you are in did not matter as much.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Really nice facilities and dorm rooms. Housing process is a huge pain.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I didn't like being pigeon-holed into living on west in my spring semester junior year after coming back from abroad.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Rooms are small for freshman, and the housing application sucks for upperclassmen
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I think a lot of these factors are dependent upon the dorm.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: I currently live in an apartment off campus, and I love it. Yes, the walls are thin, but as long you and your neighbors have an understanding at the beginning of the year about noise, everything will be fine. I love living on campus but feeling like I live off campus. Having my own kitchen and my own bathroom is great, even if I have to clean it myself. Living on Central campus makes me feel like I am going to my home away from school when I finish with classes and work for the day.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Duke's policy of three years of on campus living creates a stronger community overall.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: I had to send a medical request in to housing before I came to Duke because I have severe allergies and asthma. They approved my requests and made the accommodations to my room by the time I'd gotten here. On top of that, the rooms here at Duke are spacious compared to the rooms at some other colleges.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The campus is gorgeous. The dorms vary but there are also options to live in apartments which is fantastic.
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: There is a good number of singles, and every one I've seen has been very sizable.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Some great dorms. Some okay dorms.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Depends on the house you get. Blackwell is by far the worse in every way.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Dorms are located on East, West, and Central. Not the best quality, especially considering tuition, but it works.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: For freshman, you don't get to choose where to live as it works on a lottery. Some dorms, such as Bell Tower, are incredibly well-kept, new, have wonderful amenities, and really feel like home. Others look a bit run-down and have more trouble happening inside. As a sophomore and up, you have the option to choose where you'd like to live. You can 'rush' for a Selective Living Group (SLG) which is not a frat or sorority, more like, a dorm where people who have the same interests and values can live together. You can also choose to live in a dorm that accepts substance use, like alcohol, if you would like a place where others enjoy drinking, and you can choose a substance-free dorm as well. It all depends on your preferences. A triple room, with three beds, is the least expensive, with a single room being the most expensive. The housing process for freshman is simple, since you don't choose, and it gets a little complex as you get older, since you have to decided where to live and what to do if you want to live there.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Certain dorms are better than others. It really is just the luck of the draw and also depends on how much stuff you own.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Living on East Campus is an interesting experience, but one that I find to be valuable. There is something to be said for living alongside exclusively freshmen, so the social atmosphere is usually nice, and there is convenience in being able to walk to a grocery store.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Duke campus housing is pretty good. As a freshmen housing assignment is random and most dorms are nice except two (that tend to be really small). Beyond freshmen you have the option to live on West Campus or Central Campus based on your rankings. Usually you will get one of your 3 top choices. You are then assigned a lottery number based on your year, and even the lowest lottery numbers (like I had last year) get you a pretty good room. While roommate assignments are not always the best, I haven't had too bad of an experience, and you technically choose your own roommate. I ended up living in Few which I think is an awesome dorm, and I got to block with my friends. The dorm is in one of the best locations and the rooms are A/Ced and a reasonable size.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I've never been to an off-campus apartment, but I've heard pretty decent things about them.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I love everything about Duke. Good people, good atmosphere, good city to be in.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Durham has a great cost of living to quality of life ratio. There's a wide variety of very luxurious off-campus options for low costs.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I couldn't have made a better choice. The academic and social experiences are both great.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Great options, but the same amount of money could go a lot further in Durham.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: No experience with off campus housing.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The freshman dorms are not that  close to the main campus and my dorm is not that close to food services.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I love my dorm and find the housing process at Duke to be totally acceptable.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I know a few friends who live off-campus. Seems fine. Idk why you would tho. I love living in dorms.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: It's kind of hit-or-miss. In general, Greeks and SLGs (Selective Living Groups) control most of the best real estate, which can make it hard for independents.  The new housing model tried to rectify this, but it just ends up confusing.  Freshman dorms are great - everyone loves living on East Campus - but it can be disorienting to move off of East sophomore year and find your friends scattered around West and Central. This is a big reason for the sophomore slump.  You can end up living in Few with AC and nice rooms...or in Wannamaker with a no-substance policy, no AC, and far from everything. It's Russian Roulette.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The variety is superb! There are residential units of every sort, size, and suitability within a mile of the university.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Res Life isn't that helpful or trustworthy all inall
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Lots of different options but getting to campus can be hard
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: I love my apartment on central campus, but I wish they had better lighting and I wish that the rules weren't so strict about hosting parties in the apartments.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: The dorms are beautiful, and fantastic places to live!
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Freshman live on a separate campus that far from where the majority of classes are taught. My room was small, but I had AC and the people in my dorm were very close.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I live off-campus and LOVE it. Including utilities, it's about the same price as living on West Campus, except that I have a two-bed, two-bath apartment with washer/dryer and dishwasher. If you can afford it/have a car, I would definitely recommend living off.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Campus housing really depends on what dorm you get. I live off-campus now and not only is it cheaper than living on, but it's way more spacious.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Some are really good, while others are bad. But there are a lot of options to suit your needs. From the Brooklyn-esque housing in West Village to where most of the uppity kids live in Trinity Commons. You have to stay on campus for your first three years of school though.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Only some people do it because you have to live on campus for 3 years
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: The farther away, the cheaper it may be. Public transportation is really good.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Most students stay on campus for three years, but there a number of luxury apartments populated by seniors.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I enjoy all aspects of the campus.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: I have some friends who live on campus who think it is a great situation. I don't know about the cost or how to get a dorm, but otherwise what I know is positive.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I am married, so I was not going to live on -campus. However, my husband and I love our duplex. It is a great location for community activities, shopping, eateries etc. It's further from campus, but the safety,space and convenience is worth it.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Prices are totally reasonable compared to rent prices in big cities. Lots of nice apartment buildings close to both East and West
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: Coming into Duke I was very skeptical of the housing system at Duke. As a freshman you are on East Campus with the other freshman. I initially saw this as a negative aspect, but quickly came to love it. I still frequent Lilly library when I need to study. Sophomore year, I lived in my fraternity section on Central Campus. Again, I initially disliked central. It is somewhat dilapidated and relatively inconvenient. As the semester went on, I grew to love my section, my apartment, food fac, and my daily walk through the Gardens to get to West. I love central.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Seriously freshman housing is the only thing they get right. You have your own freshman campus which is nice, but the housing system is so stupid, I was penalized by the school for the amount of complaints I levied. They literally could care less about yu. If you have a ton of cash, chances are youre fine. But everyone else can "suck it" -- Duke University.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Its sweet, too bad you have to wait for your senior year to leave campus. Thats because duke only cares about your money, and ways to siphon it out of your pockets
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Its okay. Greek life, lax or mens ball have the most fun.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Parking is only good in the summer
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: several options and people are pretty supportive in helping you find something for your needs
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I have had an amazing freshman experience.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Required to live on campus for 3 years.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: I love my dorm, although I have one the largest triple on East Campus! Almost everyone's room is pretty spacious. Mine even has hardwood floors and walk in closets. It depends on what building you are in, though.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: You have to live on campus three of four years.  There are apartment complexes around the area for people who want to live off campus that Duke has good relationships with.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Campus housing is largely solid. Not too many issues. The lottery process is sketchy, and it is kind of easy to get screwed as an upperclassmen living on West. The first-year experience on East Campus has been one of the highlights of my time at Duke. The class unity and camaraderie it builds is lasting and helps students to get to know each other on more than a "hey" basis.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Plenty of apartments available and houses for rent. All are close to campus; most are safe and of high quality.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: It's really convenient, but you don't even need it. You're guaranteed housing all 4 years.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: At Duke, housing is guaranteed all 4 years (and required for the 1st three). That takes away a lot of the stress that my friends from other schools are facing from trying to find reasonably priced off campus housing. There is a wide range of housing options, from Central Campus apartment-style, to new, air-conditioned dorms, to dorms with classic Gothic architecture. Rooms tend to be quite spacious, or at least mine is. The freshman live on their own campus, which has its ups and downs. The positive part of that is that you get a great sense of community since you know everyone you're living with is going through the same adjustment to college period you're going through. The downside is location--you're further away from the West campus classes, but buses only take about 5-10 minutes to go back and forth between campuses, and buses come very regularly while class is in session (during the daytime). Plus, you're closer to 9th street, where there are restaurants and grocery stores.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: i live pretty far away
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: i have not utilized on campus housing
Housing.Author: Recent Alumnus

Housing.Review: East campus is for all the freshman
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: You may need a car if you choose to live off campus
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Central Campus is poor to be honest. West is great, however.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: The housing off campus is safe and comfortable. Duke provides transportation for students who live near campus.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: It is actually cheaper to have a brand new studio or 1 bedroom apartment off campus than it is to have a single or double dorm room with AC. However, Duke makes you live on campus for 3 years, so you're stuck.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Freshmen all live on East Campus, creating a sense of community among the class. Overall, the freshman dorms are relatively nice; most are not air-conditioned but it's only hot during the first couple of weeks or so. The non-air conditioned rooms have AC in the common rooms and tend to have bigger rooms while the AC dorms have smaller rooms. The main downside of the freshman East Campus setup is that freshmen may feel isolated from upperclassmen and it takes longer to get to classes on West Campus.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Housing is good but limited.  Convenience is good, everything is within walking distance.  Cost is comparable to other places.  The school is helpful with any questions.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: East Campus is great - many of the dorms are updated or even brand new. West Campus lacks many of the amenities that East Campus has, but has a prime location. Definitely a draw between the two.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: East Campus – The freshman dorm community is great. It is easy to make friends in your dorm and with your class, as all of the freshman live on one campus. However, as of this year the Duke housing model changed so it is hard to rate, or even explain, housing at the moment. After the transition, I'm sure it will be great.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Housing isn't as impressive as state schools, but each year Duke is remodeling/rebuilding the dorms, so I'm sure they'll continue to improve.
Housing.Author: College Senior

Housing.Review: Kind of Inconvenient – Much easier to live on campus. Seniors can live off campus, but it's much further away from classes and you need a car. However, it can be cheaper than living in the dorms.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Lots and Variety of Types – There is a wide range of off campus housing. The issue might be distance, especially if you don't have a car but buses and Duke transit can take you to some buildings. The off campus housing can range from very nice, spacious apartments to pretty rundown but either way the price is significantly lower than at most top schools or anything in a city.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Freshman Housing Is Great – Having the freshman housing experience is really amazing.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Join Dorms With Selective Living Groups – The best part about living on campus is being a part of a selective living group, where your dorm truly becomes your community and you can create the best social atmosphere. The first years live separately on a different campus and there, you really bond with your class. But after you move to the upperclassmen campus, there are so many dorms to choose from. Most are spacious, have air conditioning, are extremely convenient and close to restaurants, the library, class buildings, etc. You can live in a single, double, or triple, the former being the most expensive. Once you are a junior or senior, you have the option of living off campus. Also, students have the choice of living in apartment style housing.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Apartments Are Susceptible to Break-Ins – A series of break-ins have occurred in nearby communities.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: East Campus Feels Like a Community – All freshmen live on East Campus in one of ten dorms. Some dorms are big, some are tiny. Three have AC, and one, Belltower, is the newest and literally feels like a hotel. Don't let the aesthetics speak for themselves, though: the people really do make the dorm. Sororities just got housing, and they implemented a new housing system, so it will change a lot in the future years for upperclassmen.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: New Housing Model – Duke is constantly changing how they handle housing, and that can be fairly annoying when trying to decide where you want to live on campus. Everyone hates Central because they feel it is dingy and inconvenient, but overall it's not as bad as people make it seem. The ideal place to live is west because of it's relation to classes, but all freshmen live on east, which tends to be a great experience.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Pros and Cons – East Campus is just for freshman, but sharing so many things with people that don't know how to clean up after themselves gets frustrating after a while. But, all the freshman get a sense of community so that's good I suppose.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Off Campus Housing is possible, however, you are best off having a car. Also, downtown Durham is not exactly the safest area to live in, so On Campus Housing may be easier and safer.
Housing.Author: College Freshman

Housing.Review: Three Campuses: One University. Duke is divided into three campuses. You live on East Campus in with a community of freshman. You have your own library, cafeteria, gym and more. It's a great place to begin your college experience. West Campus is primarily for sophomores but there are juniors and seniors who do live on the campus. It's great living on West Campus because everything is accessible: classes, food options, library. Then there's Central Campus, which is the worst. Central is comprised of one, two and four person apartments. It's isolated from the rest of campus, the buses are always late and the apartment facilities are subpar.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Althouth you're required to live on campus for 3 yrs there's plenty of off campus apartments that are close by
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Dorms are not bad at Duke, and dining options are typical for what you might expect of a college. There is a vibrant night life.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Durham is a scary place. They're pretty cheap and some a literally just targeted to Duke undergrand, so you can do what you want with minimal noise complaints.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Many Good Options – Many good, relatively inexpensive options close to campus.  Durham Area Transit Authority and campus buses make commuting to campus w/o a car manageable (but a car is recommended).  The city of Durham has great character.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Worth It! For the first three years at least. The freshmen all live together, which is a great experience, but once you're upgraded to West campus, it's absolutely amazing. That's where all the parties are. The dorms are very well-sized and almost all have walk-in closets. If you don't get air conditioning, it can be bad, but I've never had that problem.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: I Have the Worst Luck – Duke is renowed for its Gothic architecture on West and its colonial red brick dorms on East. Freshman year I lived in Gilbert-Addoms, the biggest and ugliest dorm on East Campus. Despite the lack of AC and amenities, I loved my time in Gilbert-Addoms. The fact the East is only freshman creates a great atmosphere that really encourages the formation of friendships and socialization. East is located right by downtown Durham and the social atmosphere was wonderful. Next year i'll be living in Edens. The rooms and closets are not always spacious, the windows are minimal, and the floorplan seems both illogical and labyrinthine. AC is a saving grace.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Available, Comfortable, but Transportation Hassle – As an rising sophomore, off campus housing isn't even on my mind yet. At Duke, we don't get the chance to live off campus until we are seniors, which seems sensible to me with the good setup we have on campus. Those I know who live off campus do love it and have gotten good deals. There's a variety of places to live whether houses or apartments, but in terms of location, a car is a big help.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Housing on west is fantastic, especially Few/Kilgo/Keohane, but even Edens is not the death sentence some people make it out to be. The freshman community on East is great (but no air conditioning in many dorms is unfortunate).
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Expensive Apartments – There are numerous off-campus housing options available. The general cost for living off campus matches quite closely when compared to living on campus, though you certainly could end up saving a bit of money. Off campus housing, however, is usually rather inconvenient, unless you possess a car.
Housing.Author: College Junior

Housing.Review: Living on Campus Isn't Bad – The dorms at Duke University are actually pretty good. The room I stayed in was large, although that was one of the bigger freshman dorms. However, the lack of A/C in such a hot state as North Carolina is a little bit disappointing.
Housing.Author: College Sophomore

Housing.Review: Can't Lose With Apartments – Lots of variety and great apartments to rent with affordable pricing. Some monopolies on larger houses exist with bad landlords, but those are typically in bad neighborhoods of durham where few students choose to live. Most choose to live in the many great apartment complexes
Housing.Author: College Junior
